在: 在香港和澳门，大多以标准粤语为共通口语及教学语言，学校多数会以粤语授课，以粤音作为中文的代表音；公文书面语则多以基于官话白话文的现代通用中文书面语为准，但不少词汇会采用粤语词汇（例如采用“巴士”而非“公车”，采用“鱼蛋”而非“鱼丸子”，采用“沙律”而非“色拉”）或者不跟粤语冲突的书写形式（例如“嫲嫲”写作“祖母”而非“奶奶”[12]，“苹果批”写作“苹果馅饼”而非“苹果派”，“薯仔”写作“马铃薯”而非“土豆”），音译也以粤音为准（例如“朗拿度”不写作“罗纳尔多”，“碧咸”不写作“贝克汉姆”，“比卡超”不写作“皮卡丘”），亦偶有夹杂文言.

In Hong Kong and Macao, standard Cantonese is mostly used as a common spoken language and the language of instruction. Most schools teach it in Cantonese and not as a Chinese-language voice. The official languages are mostly based on modern Chinese-language written language based on official language, but a number of terms use Cantonese terms (e.g. “bus” instead of “buses”, “fish eggs” instead of “fishballs”, “salad” instead of “sarah”) or writing in non-sale writing (e.g. “salad” to write “Grandma” instead of “Grandma” [12], “apple pie” to write “apple pie” rather than “apple pie”, “baby” to write “a potato” instead of “a potato”), and so on (e.g. “Runado” to write “Ronaldo”, “Backham” to write “Backham”, and “Backham” to write “Back Cacho”), and there are occasional notes.
